reasoning:
The critique targets a central load-bearing move in the essay: that “mostly-great”/“near-best” futures are rare because many plausible moral views make value highly sensitive to particular dimensions (scale, population ethics, digital welfare, bads, etc.). If the essay’s talk of “catastrophe” were just semantic drift from ‘non-maximal,’ then the rhetorical and practical upshot (“great futures are hard”) would be much weaker, so centrality is high.

However, the critique only partly undercuts the argument. The essay explicitly defines catastrophe/value in cardinal terms (0–1 with extinction at 0 and best-feasible at 1) and is openly willing to accept that very attractive-looking futures might still be <0.5 on some views; that’s not an inadvertent collapse but a substantive claim defended via (i) unbounded/linear scaling and (ii) bounded-but-separately-aggregating sensitivity to bads. So the critique’s charge that the thesis becomes non-discriminating is somewhat overstated; the thesis is meant to be discriminating in relative-to-best terms, not ordinary-language “grim vs great.” Still, the critique does raise a real pressure: without further justification for treating these maximizing/fussy views as not “pathological,” the essay risks relying on a notion of ‘catastrophe’ that many will see as merely ‘not cosmic optimum,’ and the essay itself flags fanatical implications as odd—tension the critique highlights.

Correctness is fairly high: it accurately notes that on linear-in-resources views a solar-system utopia is tiny relative to cosmic expansion, and that on separate-aggregation bounded views tiny fractions of bads can ruin ‘mostly-great.’ But it overreaches by implying the essay is simply using “catastrophe” as “anything suboptimal” across the board; the essay’s thresholding (0.5/0.9) and its attempt to argue these views are plausible makes it more than a purely verbal maneuver.

Clarity is high and it is mostly one cohesive objection (moral-language/criterion drift and resulting non-discrimination), with minimal dead weight.
title: Defining "catastrophe" as suboptimality makes the thesis trivially true
